field.p: The annual financial statements have been prepared in accordance with applicable accounting standards.
The primary method used to value the items recorded in the accounts is the historical cost method.
General accounting principles have been applied with due regard to the prudence principle, based on the following assumptions:

ul.li: Going concern;
Consistency of accounting methods from one period to another;
Independence of accounting periods.

div.p: Intangible assets are valued at their acquisition or production cost, including all expenses necessary to prepare these assets for their intended use. This valuation is net of any trade discounts, rebates, or settlement discounts obtained.
Tangible assets are valued at their acquisition cost, which includes:

ul.li: The purchase price (including customs duties and non-recoverable taxes, less any trade discounts, rebates, or settlement discounts);
Directly attributable costs incurred to bring the asset to working condition for its intended use;
When applicable, the initial estimate of dismantling, removal, and site restoration costs related to the asset's location.

div.p: Tangible assets are also valued at their production cost where applicable.
Interest on borrowings specifically related to the production of tangible assets is not included in the production cost of these assets.
The following decisions have been made regarding the presentation of the annual financial statements:

ul.li: Componentized assets: The company was unable to identify componentized assets, or the decomposition of such assets does not have a material impact.
Non-componentized assets: Benefiting from tolerance measures, the company has chosen to maintain the existing useful life periods for the depreciation of non-componentized assets.

Renovations: 10 years

Software: 3 years

div.p: Depreciation is calculated using either the straight-line or declining balance method, based on the estimated useful life of the assets.
Research and development costs are recognized as expenses in the period in which they are incurred.
Given the innovative nature of the company's activities, a substantial portion of its expenses pertains to development costs as defined by applicable accounting standards

At each reporting date, and whenever there is an indication of impairment, the capitalized development costs are reviewed to confirm that the project continues to meet the criteria for recognition as an asset. If these criteria are no longer met, an impairment loss or exceptional amortization is recorded accordingly.

ul.li: First In, First Out (FIFO)
Weighted Average Cost
Standard Cost

field.p: The gross value of goods and supplies includes the purchase price and related incidental costs.
Manufactured products are valued at production cost, which includes consumables, direct and indirect production expenses, and depreciation of assets used in production.
Costs related to under-activity are excluded from the inventory value.

ul.li: Please specify the method used to calculate inventory write-downs.

div.p: The gross value consists of the purchase cost, excluding incidental expenses. When the inventory value is lower than the gross value, a provision for impairment is recorded for the amount of the difference.

ul.li: The equity method is used for valuation where applicable.
The exemption for valuation of securities in case of abnormal and temporary decline is applied.

div.p: Receivables and payables are recorded at their nominal value.

Where applicable, receivables are depreciated through provisions to account for potential collection difficulties. These provisions for impairment are determined by comparing the acquisition value with the probable realizable value.
Receivables and payables denominated in foreign currencies are converted into euros using the exchange rate at the invoice date.
Cash on hand and bank balances are recorded at their nominal value

For cash held in foreign currencies, amounts are converted into euros at the exchange rate prevailing on the last business day before the fiscal year-end. Any resulting exchange differences are recognized immediately in the income statement as foreign exchange gains or losses.

Advances received from public or private organizations to finance the company's activities, for which repayment is conditional, are presented under equity in the balance sheet as "Other Equity." Corresponding interest expenses are recorded as liabilities under "Loans and Other Financial Debts."
Loan issuance costs, where applicable, are recognized as expenses in the financial year during which the loans are granted.
Capital increase costs are recorded directly on the balance sheet as a deduction from the share premium.

The company has received subsidies that are recognized in operating income in proportion to the expenses incurred. As a result, subsidies receivable may be recorded when the grant agreement is signed and eligible expenses have been incurred, even if the funds have not yet been received.

The portion of subsidies that finance capital expenditures is recognized in operating income over the same period as the depreciation of the related assets. The acquired portion not yet recognized in income is recorded under equity as investment grants.
Operating subsidies are recorded as income as soon as they are granted.
